problem.markdown:
>>1. What is the main purpose of upstream contributions in the Open edX project?<< (!) To locally add custom code specific to your project (x) To send custom code back to the main project for community use ( ) To create a private repository for personal use ( ) To avoid any further code reviews
>>2. What is the first step in starting to contribute a feature upstream?<< (x) Reviewing the Product Roadmap (!) Posting in Slack that you are submitting a new feature ( ) Directly opening a pull request ( ) Refactoring existing code
>>3. What should you include in every feature request or product proposal ticket? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Provide context for the feature [!] Describe a suggested program implementation {{Selected: This is not a requirement, but you can suggest program implementation.}} [x] Write clearly but concisely [x] Provide a statement of why this feature is valuable for the platform [x] Provide a link to deeper context, when needed
>>4. When reporting a security issue for the Open edX project, what should you do?<< (!) Post it publicly on GitHub ( ) Discuss it in the community forum ( ) Make a pull request to fix the issue (x) Email a report to security@openedx.org
>>5. What elements make a good bug report? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Clearly state what the bug is [!] Complain about the bug [x] Clearly state how to reproduce the bug [x] Provide screenshots or a video of a screen capture [x] State what system the bug was found on
>>6. Where should you go if you have questions about how an Open edX platform feature should work?<< (x) Engage with the product team on the feature request or roadmap ticket (!) Open a GitHub Issue ( ) Post in the Development category on the forums ( ) Email the core contributors directly
>>7. If you work for a company that also works on the Open edX platform, which CLA might you use?<< (!) The individual CLA always (x) The entity CLA if contributions are related to your company’s work ( ) No CLA is necessary ( ) An individual CLA regardless of employer status
>>8. What is a pull request (PR) according to GitHub?<< (!) A method to share status updates (x) A proposal to merge a set of changes from one branch into another ( ) A product proposal of a new feature ( ) An internal review system
>>9. Which ways can be used to rerun CI/CD tests within the ``openedx`` repositories?? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Push a new commit [!] Close the PR and open a new one [ ] Shut down the CI/CD pipeline [x] Push an empty commit using ``git commit --allow-empty -m "temp: empty commit"`` [x] Rebase the pull request atop master or main [x] Squash commits, or reword a commit, using interactive rebase [x] Close the PR and re-open it
>>10. Which aspect of a PR description can speed up the review process?<< (x) Providing a detailed summary with appropriate context, links, and screenshots (!) Keeping the summary short and vague ( ) Using as few technical terms as possible ( ) Including extensive criticism of current codebase issues
>>11. What is a draft pull request primarily used for?<< (!) Ensuring no one makes comments on your pull request ( ) Finalizing code that is ready for review (x) Opening a pull request that isn’t ready to be reviewed yet ( ) Creating a placeholder for future code
>>12. When submitting a pull request (PR), which steps should you follow? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Use a draft PR until tests pass and the PR is ready for review [x] Flesh out the summary, following the repo’s PR template if present [x] Ensure tests pass locally before submitting [x] Rebase atop master frequently [x] Accept feedback openly [x] Communicate potential delays
>>13. What tool does the Open edX project use for continuous integration (CI) testing?<< (x) GitHub Actions (!) Jenkins ( ) CircleCI ( ) Travis CI
>>14. How often should you rebase your pull request to keep it from getting stale?<< (!) Every month (x) Every week ( ) Every day ( ) Rebasing is not required
>>15. What is the role of the CLA Check in CI tests for Open edX?<< ( ) Ensure frontend code is running correctly (x) Verify if your submission is covered under a CLA ( ) Validate performance metrics ( ) None of the above
>>16. How should you handle feedback on your pull request?<< [!] Ignore it [x] Be thorough, thoughtful, and polite [ ] Argue against it [ ] Dismiss it as unnecessary [x] Ask for additional detail or context when unsure what the feedback means [x] Respectfully and courteously explain your reasoning when disagreeing with it
>>17. What does a Community PR Manager provide updates about?<< (!) General community questions (x) Status of your pull request ( ) Only enhancement requests ( ) How to fix a PR’s failing tests
>>18. To ensure a PR is ready for review, what should you include in the PR summary? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Why the PR is needed [x] Links to previous feature requests, product proposals, or bug reports [x] Steps for bug reproduction or feature testing [x] Screenshots and/or videos [x] Open questions or concerns, if there are any
>>19. What categories should you focus on when asking and answering development questions in the forums?<< (!) Site Operators and its subcategories (x) Development and its subcategories ( ) Educators and its subcategories ( ) Working Groups and its subcategories
>>20. What should you do if you can't address feedback on your PR right away? (Select all that apply)<< [x] Leave a comment stating your time limitations [ ] Delete the PR [x] Be honest about what you don’t know [!] Resubmit the PR without changes
problem.label: 1. What is the main purpose of upstream contributions in the Open edX project?

choicegroup.choice: To locally add custom code specific to your project
To send custom code back to the main project for community use
To create a private repository for personal use
To avoid any further code reviews

problem.label: 2. What is the first step in starting to contribute a feature upstream?

choicegroup.choice: Posting in Slack that you are submitting a new feature

problem.label: 3. What should you include in every feature request or product proposal ticket? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Provide context for the feature
Describe a suggested program implementation This is not a requirement, but you can suggest program implementation.
Write clearly but concisely
Provide a statement of why this feature is valuable for the platform
Provide a link to deeper context, when needed

problem.label: 4. When reporting a security issue for the Open edX project, what should you do?

choicegroup.choice: Discuss it in the community forum
Make a pull request to fix the issue

problem.label: 5. What elements make a good bug report? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Clearly state what the bug is
Complain about the bug
Clearly state how to reproduce the bug
Provide screenshots or a video of a screen capture
State what system the bug was found on

problem.label: 6. Where should you go if you have questions about how an Open edX platform feature should work?

choicegroup.choice: Engage with the product team on the feature request or roadmap ticket
Post in the Development category on the forums

problem.label: 7. If you work for a company that also works on the Open edX platform, which CLA might you use?

choicegroup.choice: The entity CLA if contributions are related to your company’s work
An individual CLA regardless of employer status

problem.label: 8. What is a pull request (PR) according to GitHub?

choicegroup.choice: A method to share status updates
A proposal to merge a set of changes from one branch into another
A product proposal of a new feature

problem.label: 9. Which ways can be used to rerun CI/CD tests within the ``openedx`` repositories?? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Push a new commit
Close the PR and open a new one
Shut down the CI/CD pipeline
Push an empty commit using ``git commit --allow-empty -m "temp: empty commit"``
Rebase the pull request atop master or main
Squash commits, or reword a commit, using interactive rebase
Close the PR and re-open it

problem.label: 10. Which aspect of a PR description can speed up the review process?

choicegroup.choice: Providing a detailed summary with appropriate context, links, and screenshots
Keeping the summary short and vague
Using as few technical terms as possible
Including extensive criticism of current codebase issues

problem.label: 11. What is a draft pull request primarily used for?

choicegroup.choice: Ensuring no one makes comments on your pull request
Finalizing code that is ready for review
Opening a pull request that isn’t ready to be reviewed yet
Creating a placeholder for future code

problem.label: 12. When submitting a pull request (PR), which steps should you follow? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Use a draft PR until tests pass and the PR is ready for review
Flesh out the summary, following the repo’s PR template if present
Ensure tests pass locally before submitting
Rebase atop master frequently
Accept feedback openly
Communicate potential delays

problem.label: 13. What tool does the Open edX project use for continuous integration (CI) testing?
14. How often should you rebase your pull request to keep it from getting stale?
15. What is the role of the CLA Check in CI tests for Open edX?

choicegroup.choice: Ensure frontend code is running correctly
Verify if your submission is covered under a CLA

problem.label: 16. How should you handle feedback on your pull request?

checkboxgroup.choice: Ignore it
Be thorough, thoughtful, and polite
Argue against it
Dismiss it as unnecessary
Ask for additional detail or context when unsure what the feedback means
Respectfully and courteously explain your reasoning when disagreeing with it

problem.label: 17. What does a Community PR Manager provide updates about?

choicegroup.choice: How to fix a PR’s failing tests

problem.label: 18. To ensure a PR is ready for review, what should you include in the PR summary? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Why the PR is needed
Links to previous feature requests, product proposals, or bug reports
Steps for bug reproduction or feature testing
Screenshots and/or videos
Open questions or concerns, if there are any

problem.label: 19. What categories should you focus on when asking and answering development questions in the forums?
20. What should you do if you can't address feedback on your PR right away? (Select all that apply)

checkboxgroup.choice: Leave a comment stating your time limitations
Delete the PR
Be honest about what you don’t know
Resubmit the PR without changes
